metadata.title: The Moon and Us
metadata.objective: Understand phases and tides: how sunlight and geometry create phases, and how the Moon’s gravity helps drive tides.

narration.voiceOver: Tonight we’ll visit our Moon. I’ll point out what appears on screen and guide you through three choices. I’ll speak first; you can answer in your own time.

show.text: Phases come from sunlight and the Moon’s position, not from the Moon changing shape.

narration.voiceOver: Question one. Why does the Moon have phases? Option A: the Moon changes shape. Option B: sunlight lights different parts as the Moon orbits Earth. I’ll help you see it.

show.text: Why does the Moon have phases?

extra.b: Sunlight lights different parts as it orbits

show.text: Right—what we see is the lit part from our point of view.
The Moon’s shape stays the same; the lit piece we can see changes with position.

question.text: Why does the Moon have phases?

choices.text: Sunlight lights different parts as it orbits

teachingMoments.a: The Moon’s shape doesn’t change—the lit portion we see does.
teachingMoments.b: Exactly—phases are about light and geometry.

narration.voiceOver: Question two. What causes ocean tides? Option A: ocean animals moving in groups. Option B: gravity from the Moon and Sun tugging on Earth’s water. Choose when you’re ready.

extra.b: Gravity from the Moon and Sun

show.text: Right—gravity pulls water into bulges that move as Earth rotates.
Animals don’t move the whole ocean—gravity does that.

choices.text: Gravity from the Moon and Sun

teachingMoments.a: Animals can stir water locally, but tides are gravity at work.
teachingMoments.b: Exactly—gravity pulls water into bulges that track with the Moon and Sun.

narration.voiceOver: Question three. What is a helpful way to learn Moon phases? Option A: memorize names only. Option B: notice the shape and which side is lit, and track it for a week. I’ll share why that works.

show.text: What is a helpful way to learn Moon phases?

extra.b: Track shape and which side is lit for a week

show.text: Yes—observing the lit side and shape builds real understanding.
Memorizing names helps some, but noticing the lit side and shape over days makes it click.

question.text: What is a helpful way to learn Moon phases?

choices.text: Track shape and which side is lit for a week

teachingMoments.a: Names are a start; observing brings it to life.
teachingMoments.b: Exactly—observe the lit side and shape to understand phases.

narration.voiceOver: Your takeaway: look up tonight and notice the Moon’s shape and which side shines. Understanding grows when you track it for a week—simple, calm, and true.

show.text: Track the Moon for a week—shape and lit side. Understanding follows observation.
